awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Astrophysics and Planetary Science at Cornell University
awd_abstract_narration:
Cornell University will host a summer REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) program in astronomy and planetary science. Each summer, ten students will spend ten weeks at Cornell engaged in research in Space Sciences. The program will strive to recruit diverse cohorts including students from underrepresented groups, students from colleges and universities with limited local research infrastructure, and students with unusual academic careers. Students will work within a small research group involved in groundbreaking science, attend a series of lectures and workshops, and participate in other activities that will introduce them to broader scientific topics as well as the nature of professional careers in astronomy and the processes by which major facilities and missions are designed, constructed, and deployed. The research and professional development programs will help students to understand the nature and ethics of scientific research and the skills and process necessary to become a professional scientist. 

Students will participate in on-going astronomy programs at Cornell including the Carl Sagan Institute, the North American Nanohertz Observatory for Gravitational Waves (NANOGrav) and LIGO collaborations, the Cornell instrument group. Cornell planetary scientists are actively engaged in the Cassini, Juno, Europa Clipper, Mars Science Laboratory and Mars2020 Rover missions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Cornell’s Research Experience for Undergraduates in Astronomy and Astrophysics is a ten-week residential summer program for students that have limited access to research resources at their home institutions yet show potential for scientific research and for whom immersion in a program at a major research university would provide great benefit. Participants benefit from a complete professional development experience involving scientific research projects, and integrated development of professional skills vital to the workforce of tomorrow. We 

  • Seek to contribute to the pipeline of future scientists and STEM professionals and increase access to careers in the astronomical field by recruiting students from colleges and universities without major astronomy research programs who
    • have not previously had off-campus research experiences
    • have non-traditional academic backgrounds
    • Combine Cornell’s strengths in broad areas of the research frontier with our experience and commitment to involve undergraduates in all aspects of research. We provide students independent research opportunities under the mentorship of our faculty and their teams and expose them to broad areas of current research, fostering appreciation of the research enterprise and their possible place within it.
    • Provide students with the key insight that science is the product of collaboration—that novel ideas stem from groups of individuals that support and challenge each other.

We responded to the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic by running remote programs in 2020 and 2021, with a one week in person final symposium for both cohorts in 2021. We

  • Ensured all students, including those from underprivileged backgrounds had the computing resources necessary to conduct their research.
    • Provided students with encrypted laptops (secured via a budget supplement) with all necessary software and data.
      • Students returned the laptops at the end, to be used by succeeding cohorts.
    • Ensuring all had the necessary connectivity.
  • Leveraged various remote work platforms.
  • Increased mentor training efforts.
  • Assumed a leading role with other Cornell summer programs to
    • virtually recreate in-person activities and lectures
    • provide opportunities to socialize.
  • Leveraged Cornell’s membership in the Leadership Alliance, a national consortium of major U.S. higher education institutions.
  • Leveraged  our network of REU alumni to provide additional networks and career path guidance.

The 2022 program returned to campus.

Program activities were designed to:

  • help students explore areas of astrophysics and planetary science different from what they do research on via a lecture series in-depth workshops providing a synthesis of cutting-edge topics;
  • help them develop critical professional skills (independent problem solving, interacting and communicating in teams, working on interdisciplinary projects, data management, finding and understanding relevant literature, scientific, statistical, and parallel computing skills, science communications);
  • educate them in the nature, methodology and ethics of scientific research;
  • help them understand the career paths open to them.
